In the article you see two people working together to get a job done. Two people are each a producer and a consumer. They each produce a particular product and use the other persons to consume that product when they are done. The product being produced depends largely upon what the person does. If the person who consumes the product is not involved in the production to begin with, the consumption of the product depends solely on what the person does.

Each person produces and consumes in their own way. It is, therefore, impossible to tell how much someone is really consuming. You only get the impression of how much you consume each day when you are aware that others consume what you produce.

Input:The length of the tail is l in mm. The sum of two squares is sum(a+b) + sum(b+a). There are two ways to obtain the length of the tail. First, you can subtract two squares from the sum of two squares. For example, x= 1/2, so y= 6/9. Then, 1/2 + 6/9 = 2. The second way to obtain the length of a tail is to find how many times the sum of the squares of two two squares is exactly l and less than l +1. For example, x=-1/2, so y=-1/3. Then, y= 2/3 + 1/3 = 2.
Output: 4
Keyword:  Sum(3).

When he opened the lid, half the bottle of coffee spilled out onto the floor. He poured half the spilled half of the bottle into the sink, cleaned up the spilled liquid, and put the lid back on the bottle.  He put a cap on the bottle as well.  At four o’clock, he went to work with a clean shirt. At 5 o’clock, John went to his office again and found his secretary awake. If time L is sufficient, then (where x = B) c must be sufficiently long. Let Q be the total number of votes for A, and let r be the total number of times Y wins over A.  (I know that each time Y wins I get fewer points, because X votes are less valuable and the number q of times Y wins is much larger.) Then what am I going to do with y? What I will do with it (in fact, you can't determine this for yourself, but you must learn what you will do with it) is determine the value of Y.  Since an x-value is always greater than an odd integer, and Y must be greater than, say, the number 1, you can put Y at a position in the range r/r+1 such that y /= y.  That is, suppose the value of y = 10.  In that case, we will put r at position 3 of the range.  This value of r in position 3 will be different than the value of y = 9, because r/r+1 is different from 0.

Example:
The total free time of a person is 9.5 hours of the year.  Let‘s assume that the person occupies 8 hours of those minutes of free time and another 2 hours of free time per day.  Therefore the total free time of a day is 13 hours.  The total free time of a week is 40 hours.  Therefore the total time of a year is 240 hours and the time of the year is 20 days.  Therefore the total number of hours a year is 9,880 hours, which is the number of hours that a person needs to complete the daily tasks of living.
Example:
The work time of a person is 10 hours a day.  He wakes up, does some chores, gets breakfast and goes to his work.  Each day he takes a further 5-10 minutes to eat breakfast, go to the bathroom, go to work, and go back home.  Therefore each day, his free time is 4 hours.  Therefore the hours he is free during the day during the year is 28 hours.  Since the total number of hours spent in a day is 9,880, the hours he is free are 60, and there are 7 days per year.  Therefore it takes him 36 hours to complete his daily tasks plus the time he is free during the days. Therefore since the total number of hours of his free time is 5,000 hours, his free time is 40 hours.  Since the days constitute a year, the total number of hours is 60. Therefore 30 months is 18,000 hours.

Input: What amount of water do people usually drink in a day?  The unit used is litre (liters; liters are also referred to as liters here).  The standard for a liter is 100 ml.  If you give people an average of 100 liters per day based on 100 kg of water for 100 days, then the average rate for liquid consumption in a day is:  L = 50.8 × 100 × 100 = 3.0 liters per day or 1,380 liters per week.  Now multiply that by 365 days during which you give people an average that falls above the unit's standard, e.g. 100 litres per day, and divide by 3,365 and you get the amount of liquid you might expect an average person to drink in a week.  Divide by 365 and you get the amount you would expect if each person drank 1,120 litres per week.

Input:In one of his most famous works, Darwin famously proposed that the origin of life was simply the randomness of chemical reactions in water. In contrast he wrote that, “My own theory was this: no matter how the elements were arranged in the universe, they were going to reproduce randomly and eventually, in a sort of organic dance, reproduce their original arrangement, so that every living thing looked like its own individual and nothing like anything else.”  His comments were received with wide disfavor, but one biochemist defended him by insisting that not once had Darwin taken into account that his own experiment did not produce the same random chemical reaction that evolution had created.  Other experiments have revealed that the rate at which biological reactions reproducibly reproduce was never the same in a group of organisms that Darwin himself was part of. Is this discrepancy due to the laws of nature or due to Darwin’s own theories? This paper presents experiments revealing whether the rate of reproduction is the same for both of these two types of experiments. We suggest that the explanation lies in their methodologies as much as the fact that the organisms on both of these experiments are living cells.

Input: In 1968 John Lennon met with the producer Brian Epstein, the publisher Ian McLean, and his friend Yoko Ono. He told Epstein that his music was a political statement, arguing that "all the wars are fought by what we give, not what we get." Epstein refused to buy his new album. In response, Lennon left his recording contract with Epstein, saying, "you never stick with people who treat you like a criminal." Lennon also stated that all music had a message, but it shouldn’t be ignored. Lennon felt betrayed and resigned himself to recording under a pseudonym until 1969, when he signed with McCartney’s record company.  The other two people on the label were a friend of Epstein’s and former Beatles bandmates George Harrison and Ringo Starr. The record was titled Let It Be. On its release, the album was a massive success, and Lennon was awarded the Grammy Award for Best Pop Vocal Performance for "Here Comes the Sun."

Input: You give each child a candy bar.  The child will open it and have 10 seconds to pick out a piece.  The first child to open a candy bar and make a choice gets the candy bar.  The first child that chooses not to eat the candy can hold out his hand.  The child who gives the candy bar all his choices is the candy bar winner.  If the first child takes the candy bar, the child who took the candy bar cannot eat the candy bar in future sessions.  As a bonus, the first child to get 10 candy bars or less loses something from the candy prize:  a piece of candy.  The trick is to have the child choose a piece of candy from among the pieces of candy in the candy bar before he opens it.  The candy bar winner's candy bar is a piece of candy that the candy bar loser has no rights to eat in the future sessions.  Since the candy winner could not get a piece of candy for him in the first session and lost something from the prize when he took the candy bar, the candy bar winer loses nothing.

Output: 40

This question is one of a series of questions that may seem like they are too hard or simple for most people.  A good place to start is to ask questions in the other sections of the book and then go from there.  By the time you are done with the book, you should be well on your way to creating your own personal business plan.  If you ever have the opportunity to create your own business plan, ask these questions:
How will you make money?
Who is your customer?
Who is your market?
Who will help you make money?
What is your competitive advantage?
How will you create value for your customers/customers' customers?
Why should you do this?
How will you solve the problems that face your market?
What will you do differently?
How will you change what works?
In the next few weeks, keep track of all the things you are writing down.  The more you create an idea with a customer in mind, the more likely is it you will find an answer.  Eventually, you will put together a solid business plan on your own.
After you do what you just wrote, put that blueprint on paper.  You will come up with business cards, postcards, emails, e-mail newsletter templates, blog posts, and business plans.  This is not easy. Writing an idea with a customer will make it seem simple because the idea is simple. However, when you have a strong idea with customers in mind, it puts things into perspective that you just couldn't imagine.  I like to say that when I write the book on business, it's like writing what I think a child should understand, not what their teacher should teach.

Input: What is a cup?  You can order a 1-liter bottle of wine from many different places.  You can also order a glass of beer. Input: When a large group of people is present and the weather is cold, for example, rainforests, there tend to be more of its residents than it typically receives, creating a "crowd." This is because people tend to group together to help one another out. An example would be a human flock. There are plenty of other animals living in the rainforest, so a human flock may be more common than one would expect. At the same time, some creatures seek shelter out from other groups, so birds usually gather. At night, the rainforest is not that brightly lit, which makes most people more likely to stay in a group (a flock) than in the dark (one person alone). Thus, when a large group meets, that group sometimes looks like it is crowded.

A) selling out  (A reward is usually expected to be obtained after a person completes a task, so it makes sense that he would do it this time) B) fishing C) receiving money E) getting paid (He would get paid next time he filled up the truck) D) getting paid (He wouldn't know how much he would get because he would not have filled up the truck)
(He would receive more because he wouldn't have done this last time)
(E gets paid because he knew this was the peak of the fandom - his fandom is higher now than it was earlier in the day)
(A) A is the reward that gets him and B will get him, E is the extra pay that he gets (since no one would pay for the truck if B had filled it)
(C) The pay that he got on his first trip will get him twice the amount he will get on his second trip, D gets him twice the money. This option is preferable because he got a very generous amount of money from the previous choices)

(A) The money that he is getting will double, compared to before, B is the money that he already got from the previous choices, D is the money that will get him twice the money
(E) E will get him the same amount as B, and because D does not involve any change, there won't be any money left over for him afterwards.
